[h1] A good start to continue the story [/h1]

A very entertaining sequel to the events of Half-Life 2, it is considerably short in length, but the story and gameplay are kept up at a very good pace, so it continues to be of excellent quality.

Half-Life 2, like its predecessor, changed the world of gaming and the FPS genre, and after that, they decided to expand the universe of this story, adding to the list a series composed of 2 episodes located directly after the events of Half-Life 2, from which Half-Life 2 Episode One, the first episode of the series, originates.

[list]
 [*] This expansion, like everything that makes up Half-Life 2, works from the iconic Source graphics engine, which in addition to allowing us to do crazy things in Gmod, is very well polished and offers a large number of different scenarios thanks to its physics .

 [*] Similar to the case of the graphic engine, a setting is achieved at the level of the original title, for reasons of the history of the expansion of course they vary and the same types of environments are not in the same amounts as before, but it does achieve that characteristic immersion from Half Life 2.

 [*] We're referring to a title from over 10 years ago, so we can't expect RTX capability, 4K resolution, and any number of other crazy exclusives from current games, however, it has really held up well in physical appearance, and It is something very typical of the source engine and the design of characters and models on the part of Valve, since, no matter how much time passes, they do not come to look like weird dolls without souls, since (in my opinion) they have their own charisma and distinctive, similar to what happens with classic DOOM titles and other classics in the same genre.

 [*] Half-Life 2 Episode one (like Episode Two) are expansions, but very peculiar at the story level, because it is not like the cases of Opposing force and Blue Shift in Half-Life 1, which are stories different, but in a single timeline, but are a direct continuation, as if it were a sequel to Half-Life 2 fragmented into small pieces. The story deepens the characters much more than before, making them react a little more realistically than before, but this is not fully exploited, since this game formula fragmented into small chapters means that each episode has a mini ending, causing that in the case of this episode, everything turned out too fast for me and despite the story being very enjoyable, its duration seems to be taken from a low-budget indie game, so it depends on how each one takes it.

 [*] Campaign action changes a bit, but not really for the worse. I like the fact that the type of action varies depending not on the game, but on the story itself, which is something that was developed more than anything in Half-Life 2, changing from puzzles to horror, or pure action. In this case they focused mostly on horror and action puzzle solving, something I haven't seen so much in use since the last few parts of Opposing Force, and it was something I really liked. It could be said that in gameplay it is Opposing force only without having Dark souls difficulty and bugs involved.
[/list]

Half-Life 2 Episode One despite being considerably short (or short enough to become a problem at least for me) has really kept the essence of Half-Life 2 and gives a very good start at the level of history and gameplay to what follows after Half-Life 2.

With sirens blaring, the distant stomps of striders in the distance, and the slowly disintigrating Citadel with a dimension-breaking rift looming overhead, you find yourself right at its front door, armed with little more than your gravity gun and hope. Good Luck.

Half-Life 2: Episode 1 reflects the overall gameplay progression and flow of the original Half-Life 2, but instead focuses slightly more on puzzle-solving and player ingenuity. The game presents the inclusion of Alyx Vance, the plucky young rebel with a penchant for guerilla science and a nose for terrible puns, as a faux-cooperative element throughout your adventures as you try to beat the clock and escape the destructive zone of the volatile Citadel. Whether it be by helping you reconfigure a rollermine, or taking out zombines with a sniper rifle, Alyx is quick with encouragement as well as plenty of introspective and character-building dialogue that is quite vacant in Half-Life 2. 

So while this review is short, much like this first episode; I must say that Valve took an interesting step towards innovative gameplay mechanics, functionality, as well as interaction with a companion NPC that is quite charming and fun!

8/10

I jumped back into this game right after completing Half-Life 2, without skipping a beat. After having completed both Black Mesa and Half-Life: Alyx, I was hungry for more and decided to replay the previous entries in the story. By far I remembered Episode One the least, especially how short it was. Not much seems to happen in this chapter where Gordon and Alyx escape City 17 with Barney and the rest of the fleeing citizens, at least compared to Episode Two, but I enjoyed reacquainting with the details I'd either forgotten or glossed over. Details like how the Combine wanted the Citadel to melt down so they could send an information packet across our universe to theirs, which, among other things, contained a video from Dr. Judith Mossman taken at the Resistance's Northern base. This explains why you still encountered Combine soldiers and other post-humans on their side: first they wanted to stop you from containing the Citadel's reactor and delaying the meltdown, then they wanted to stop you from taking the packet to White Forest, where Eli Vance and Kleiner continued their work. Of course, the main appeal of this episode is fighting alongside Alyx Vance as you made your way out of City 17. Merle Dandridge is so warm and fun as Alyx, and unlike the old videogame design trope of annoying escort missions, she's more than capable of holding her own as well as lending you a hand against zombies and Combine. Likewise her dynamic with Dr. Kleiner and her father Eli is always a delight. 

If you just want a quick refresher to get you up to speed before or after playing Half-Life: Alyx, play Episode One and Two.
